title: rituals vs. sprints: working with creative energy
content:

on creative practices & how i work

today I want to share two modes of working that have formed the backbone of my creative, digital, and business practices: working in ongoing rituals vs. in intensive, focused sprints.

I describe this as the difference between the daily (sometimes tedious) practice of tending to a garden â€” versus the focused (often adrenaline-infused high) of riding an energy wave to complete a creative project.

Iâ€™ll explore

  • my framework for each mode of working

  • how to decide which way suits your current projects, and

  • how to move fluidly between them in your daily work life

ritual work is gardening work

you probably know by now that my work is made up of gardening metaphors â€” I approach digital businesses as labyrinths, and creative content ideas as biodiversity in a web world ecosystem. this is why my podcast about art/internet/business is called the botanical studies of internet magic.

but before all of that, I first began by relating to the daily ritual as the act of tending to a garden. this garden could be: your creative practice, your business, your website/online ecosystem. but also, a garden could represent your relationship to: your body, your intimate relationships, your home, the integrity of your own mind. anything you care about enough to be present with it, in an ongoing way.

this work of you continually showing up â€” regardless of external/internal weather conditions, circumstances, or level of resistance / reluctance / boredom â€” is the labor of love you give to keep something alive. it is your intention, energy, and time. this doesnâ€™t necessarily mean everyday or every week; it might include periods in which you disappear, go on metaphorical vacation, and hope your plants donâ€™t die. but when you have a garden, no matter how long your absence, you always come back to take care of it. the point isnâ€™t never leaving; itâ€™s coming back. over time, you learn to find your own rhythm of presence with your garden. and, your own process.

you build rituals in order to support your tending and continual return to your practices. I have different gardening rituals for every aspect of my creative work and business systems. these rituals are like containers that help me be on autopilot mode â€” it helps me silence the indecisions and noise in my head so that I can be even more deeply in the creative flow.


sprints is riding energy waves

the sprint way of working is to focus intensely on a creative project deadline for a clearly defined, consecutive container of time. most of my sprints are between 1-3 days.

sprints are different from rituals in that they

  • have a clear creative output

  • have a deadline

  • need advance planning, ie:

    • need energy reserves + energetic/creative attunement

    • need an incubation period before

    • have energetic limitations in how often you can do it

  • need a hibernation / rest period after

this is why I think about sprints as riding a wave of creative energy and momentum, building up and accumulating towards a clear creative output. itâ€™s like a plant producing a flower/fruit, or a creature giving birth. there is intense adrenaline and birth energy in sprinting â€” it forces a kind of hyper-focus that is totally unsustainable for long periods of time. sprints force you to ruthlessly prioritize. you donâ€™t have time to linger in the details and indecisions â€” because you have a constant awareness of a deadline. thus, the result is something both deliberately planned and â€” free and spontaneous.

containers of comfort vs. intensity

if the point of a ritual is that you can return to it anytime, as often as daily, or multiple times a day â€” in that itâ€™s a garden container that provides a sense of earthy comfort â€” then sprints are like the equivalent of having wild, brief love affairs with your creative work. they are special. they require energy, planning, deliberation, anticipation, and post-processing. and of course: always a looming sense of the ending / death process.

you are married to your rituals, but your sprints are your most passionate love affairs.

and of course, because I always think about non-duality â€” in this metaphor, any project or practice could be both a ritual or a sprint. you can nurture a 1 hour long, daily writing practice, AND/OR spend a weekend staying up until 4am, feverishly completing a first draft.

non-duality, interdependence & hybridity

sprints cannot exist without rituals â€” because without the ongoing practices of presence and tending, you wonâ€™t be able to gather the momentum and energy to channel into a specific output.

how you gather this energy and show up in your ritual is totally up to you â€” perhaps your ritual includes research, rest, doodling, dreaming, sketching, talking, or decomposting things. everything you do in rituals become raw material for your sprints.

often times Iâ€™ve found that my rituals themselves become and feel like hybrid or micro-sprints â€” whenever I write long ideas posts, make a podcast episode, or send a newsletter, Iâ€™m channeling focused energy into a 2-3 block period of time. I enter my day with a clear output in mind, a deadline, and an attunement to my energy. I can show up to do this daily, or weekly, or whenever I feel the momentum build up.

the cyclical process

Iâ€™ll leave you with a short distilled summary:

rituals and sprints are both essential containers for creative energy.

rituals nourish you, and give you the safety and foundation to be free, expressive, and spend your creative energy in focused output.

your sprints â€” and what you make from them â€” then feed back into your rituals, and infuse them with new inspiration, insight, and direction.

then, slowly, over time, some of your rituals will feel like sprints, and your sprints will feel like rituals. youâ€™ll learn to dance fluidly in between â€” earth and water, fire and air. ğŸƒ
